title: Eddie Jones explains where England need to improve to win Rugby World Cup
text:
The Red Roses had two tries disallowed against New Zealand in the semi-final (Picture: Getty)

Eddie Jones believes England will need to be more ruthless in the Rugby World Cup final and feels his side should have racked up a bigger score in their thumping win over New Zealand.

The Red Roses beat the reigning champions – who had not lost at a World Cup in 12 years – in the semi-final in Yokohama, with a second-minute try from Manu Tuilagi and four penalties from George Ford sealing a 19-7 win.

Both Sam Underhill and Ben Youngs thought they had added to score either side of half-time only for their tries to be ruled out.

Underhill and Youngs thought they had scored only for the TMO to chalk them off (Picture: Getty)

Although Jones was delighted with his side’s performance, he feels there are still areas they can improve upon when they face either Wales or South Africa in next Saturday’s final.

Asked where the side can improve, Jones told ITV after the match: ‘I think it’s just a matter of taking our opportunities.

‘We probably left two or three tries out there, I think we had two disallowed, and to win a World Cup you’ve got to take those.

‘We’ve got another week in the comp, so we’re excited about that, another prospect to work hard, see where we can take our game, see where we can get better.’

On what impressed him most against the All Blacks, Jones continued: ‘Just our tactical discipline. You play against New Zealand, if you try to play them at their game you’re going to come off second best.

Jones has played down England’s favourites tag going into next week’s final (Picture: Getty)

‘I thought we stuck to our game really well. Early on in the game, because we were getting some quick ball, we loosened up a little bit and probably missed a couple of opportunities to score, but I thought the discipline of our players was outstanding in attack and defence.’

Asked about England now being favourites to win the tournament, Jones added: ‘We don’t bet, we don’t look at the bookies, so we’re not really concerned. Our expectations are the most important thing, how we try to get better every day.’
